WAR CABINET.
SECRET.
G.T. 4940.
A Conference on Middle-Eastern Affairs was held at 10, Downing Street, S.W. on Monday, 17th June, 1918, at 4.30 p.m.
PRESENT:
The Prime Minister (In the Chair)
The Rt. Hon. the Earl Curzon of Kedleston K.G., G.C.S.I., G.C.I.E.
The Rt. Hon. A.J. Balfour, O.M.,M.P., S. of S. for Foreign Affairs.
The Rt. Hon. Viscount Milner, G.C.B., G.C.M.G., S. of S. for War.
General Sir H.H. Wilson, K.C.B., D.S.O., Chief of the Imperial General Staff.
Lt. Gen. the Rt.Hon. J.C. Smuts, K.C.
The Rt.Hon. E.S. Montagu M.P., S. of S. for India.
Lt. Gen. Sir H.V. Cox, K.C.M.G. C.B., C.S.I., India Office.
Major-General Sir G.M.W. Macdonogh, K.C.M.G., C.B., Director of Military Intelligence.
Lt.-Col. Sir M. Hankey, Secretary
Lt.-Col. L. Storr Assistant Secretary
Lt.-Col. L.S. Amery Assistant Secretary
The Conference decided:-
(1) That steps should be taken to interrupt, if possible, the Trans-Caspian railway, and that the War Office should be asked to issue the necessary instructions.
(2) That the Secretary of State for India should be invited to prepare, for the information of the War Cabinet, a Memorandum of his views.
(Initialled) M.P.A.H.
2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.
24th June, 1918.
